answers.answer: bkem,For a variety of reasons, one cannot predict with any accuracy life expectancy based simply on the ejection fraction seen on an echocardiogram. First, the ejection fraction can have considerably variability depending on many different things such as heart rate and volume status. Secondly, your functional status and comorbidities (diabetes, coronary artery disease, kidney function etc). are much more important in predicting outcomes.With that said, there are many people with heart failure who live long productive lives with little to no impairment in the activity of daily living. Good luck and hope that medical therapy will be successful in keeping you active and healthy.

question: This is the second time in 7 years that I've had cardiomyopathy.  The first time was viral related.  I started with EF of 25% and ended with 66%.  Had 4 very good years and now have it back.  My EF is 25%.  I was told that this was not normal to have it again.  I have been told that I could have sudden death with this.  They are trying medicine to see if it improves my EF.  After 6 months of trying medicine if not better they will put in a defribullator/pacemaker.  I am 49 years old.  How long can I expect to live?
title: Life expectency  with EF 25% and no defibrillator
